summary: This is a letter from U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta to retired Judge Edward B. Davis, appointing him as a Special Master to select an attorney representative for victims in the Jeffrey Epstein case. It outlines the terms of Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement regarding victim compensation and the criteria for selecting the victims' attorney.

persons.name: Edward B. Davis
persons.context: Retired judge appointed by the U.S. Attorney's Office to consult with and select an attorney representative for the identified victims in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of a federal investigation who entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office, agreeing to pay for a victims' attorney representative and waiving certain defenses in potential civil suits under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signed the letter appointing the Special Master and outlining the Epstein agreement terms.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Attorney from Kirkland & Ellis LLP representing Jeffrey Epstein, listed as a contact for the Special Master.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, formally appoints Davis as Special Master to select a victims' attorney representative.
Lefkowitz is identified as Epstein's attorney, representing him in matters related to the Non-Prosecution Agreement and victim compensation.
Davis, as Special Master, is instructed to coordinate with Lefkowitz (Epstein's counsel) regarding the selection of the victims' attorney representative.
Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office (led by Acosta) entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement outlining terms for victim compensation and legal procedures.

events.title: Appointment of Special Master
events.description: U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta appoints retired Judge Edward B. Davis as Special Master to select an attorney representative for Epstein's victims.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office and Jeffrey Epstein entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement that includes provisions for victim compensation, attorney fees, and waivers of certain legal defenses in civil suits.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office identified 34 victims under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255 in the Epstein investigation.
Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement required him to pay for a victims' attorney representative, but not for contested litigation.
Epstein waived jurisdiction and liability defenses for victims who filed suits exclusively under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255, up to an agreed damage amount.
The Special Master was instructed to select a victims' attorney with specific criteria, including experience litigating against high-profile attorneys and sensitivity to victim privacy.
